name: Fish with White Wine Sauce
description: Recipe video above. This is a beautiful, elegant white wine sauce that will go with virtually any fish. The simple restaurant trick we deploy here is to mix in cold cubes of butter which makes the sauce glossy and satiny. It's a classic French technique called monter au beurre.Don't try this sauce with baked fish (make this Baked Fish with Lemon Cream Sauce instead). You need to pan fry because the fond left in the pan after pan frying dissolves into the sauce and adds flavour.
recipeIngredient: 4   x 150g / 5oz white fish fillets (, skinless, boneless (I used snapper, Note 1))
1  eschalot (, small, finely chopped (~1 1/2 tbs, Note 2))
1 1/4 cups white wine (, dry, not sweet or too woody (chardonnay is especially good, Note 3))
1 tsp lemon juice ((sub white wine vinegar))
1 tsp white wine vinegar ((sub more lemon))
30g / 2 tbsp  unsalted butter (, cold, cut into 1cm / 1/3" cubes)

itemListElement.text: Preheat oven to 50°C/120°F. Place rack over a tray.
itemListElement.name: Preheat oven to 50°C/120°F. Place rack over a tray.

itemListElement.text: Season fish: Sprinkle fish with salt and pepper.
itemListElement.name: Season fish: Sprinkle fish with salt and pepper.

itemListElement.text: Cook fish: Heat oil in a large non stick skillet over medium high heat. Cook fish in two batches until golden, 2 minutes on each side, or until the internal temperature is 55°C/131°F. (Note 4)
itemListElement.name: Cook fish: Heat oil in a large non stick skillet over medium high heat. Cook fish in two batches until golden, 2 minutes on each side, or until the internal temperature is 55°C/131°F. (Note 4)

itemListElement.text: Keep warm: Place fish on rack, and place in the oven to keep warm.
itemListElement.name: Keep warm: Place fish on rack, and place in the oven to keep warm.

itemListElement.text: Discard oil: Tip out excess oil from the skillet but don't wipe clean.
itemListElement.name: Discard oil: Tip out excess oil from the skillet but don't wipe clean.

itemListElement.text: Reduce wine: Add eschalot, white wine, lemon juice, vinegar, salt, pepper, sugar to the pan. Bring to simmer (still on medium high) and reduce by half (~3 minutes).
itemListElement.name: Reduce wine: Add eschalot, white wine, lemon juice, vinegar, salt, pepper, sugar to the pan. Bring to simmer (still on medium high) and reduce by half (~3 minutes).

itemListElement.text: Simmer cream: Add cream, simmer for 2 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Simmer cream: Add cream, simmer for 2 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Finish with COLD butter: Turn heat to low and add cold butter one cube at a time while mixing with wooden spoon. Once all the butter is incorporated, the sauce should be thickened, satiny and beautifully glossy.
itemListElement.name: Finish with COLD butter: Turn heat to low and add cold butter one cube at a time while mixing with wooden spoon. Once all the butter is incorporated, the sauce should be thickened, satiny and beautifully glossy.

itemListElement.text: Optional strain: Strain the sauce through a sieve (discard eschalot), then pour it back into the pan.
itemListElement.name: Optional strain: Strain the sauce through a sieve (discard eschalot), then pour it back into the pan.

itemListElement.text: Fish in sauce: Place fish back into the pan in the sauce. Spoon some sauce over the fish, leave for 30 seconds.
itemListElement.name: Fish in sauce: Place fish back into the pan in the sauce. Spoon some sauce over the fish, leave for 30 seconds.

itemListElement.text: Serve: Transfer fish onto serving plates. Spoon sauce over each fish, sprinkled with parsley if desired. Pictured with a side of pea puree (great colour splash!).

review.reviewBody: Loved this recipe. Made it this evening, very easy. My husband loved the sauce!

This recipe is an absolute winner! I added freshly sliced garlic and sundried tomatoes in addition to the ingredients listed in the recipe. But otherwise, I followed the recipe for the most part. Everyone LOVED it! Make this!!

Another amazing Nagi recipe, another amazing result.

Absolutely delish.

Once again all ingredients were in the pantry and fish in the freezer.

You're the best Nagi!
great dish very quick for folks in a hurry
Thank you for this recipe. Finally have an excellent and easy fish sauce I can use any time
Best fish I've ever made in 40 years. I would eat the same thing again tonight, just amazing.

Really nice way to serve fish. My sauce was a little too runny so I could have reduced a little longer I think. Served with pea purée and roasted some pumpkin in the air fryer, everyone enjoyed and an easy mid week cook
Beautiful tasting sauce. I simmered it for far longer than directed and it didn't thicken, but still lovely.  Didn't have any shallots so used a bit of spring onion  which was fine.
This was so delicious it really felt like I was eating in a top class restaurant!

I found that I had to reduce the sauce much more so then mentioned (for at least 15 min). I don't like adding table sugar to my meals so I added pineapple juice (3 tablespoons) and apple cider vinegar (3 tablespoons). I added one tbs of flour mixed in cold water to thicken it. THEN, it was too white. So, I added a tsp of yellow curry powder which the gave it a yellow color. So, it ended up being delicious and with the pineapple and curry...a Caribbean flare. I served it with butternut squash risotto (Alessi) and roasted parm/bread crum zucchini.
So good! Everyone enjoyed this with some fried rice and veggies.
Amazing! very delicious and healthy food ever.
